description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: February 25, 2020: With Bulletin N. 90, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended a meeting with EU Health Commissioner, Stella Kyriakides, and the Ministers of Health of those countries bordering with Italy: Austria, France, Slovenia and Switzerland. The Ministers of Health of Germany and Croatia also took part in the meeting. The aim of the meeting was to share and discuss information about the epidemiological situations of COVID-19 in the States. Issues about travelling and movement of goods between countries were also discussed.

description: December 15, 2020: With Bulletin N. 317, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health attended a meeting with other European States including Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, The Netherlands, Spain and Switzerland. The aim of the meeting was to discuss the vaccination campaign and the need to coordinate efforts for the safe and efficient use of the COVID-19 vaccine. During the meeting, the Ministers agreed to promote the coordination of the vaccination campaign and the rapid sharing of information between national and international authorities. Furthermore, they agreed on a fast sharing of information and experiences in the field of pharmacovigilance. The Ministers also committed to fight disinformation and fake news over the vaccination campaign. Finally, the Health Ministers agreed on the need to ensure a clear and transparent communication to the population about vaccines.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: February 3, 2020: With Bulletin N. 42, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, attended a summit between G7 Health Ministers on COVID-19. Health Ministers include: Patricia A. Hajdu for Canada, Agnès Buzyn for France, Jens Spahn for Germany, Kato Katsunobu for Japan, Matt Hancock for the UK and Alex Michael Azar II for the US. The aim of the conference was to share information between Health Ministries of the G7. Updates about the trend of the pandemic and the epidemiological situation in each State were discussed. The Italian Minister of Health outlined to the G7 colleagues the measures taken by Italy, for example the ban of flights from China and health monitoring in ports and airports. The meeting also discussed the importance of a communal commitment to support the Chinese government in its efforts to address the emergency and underlined the need to collaborate and share all scientific information useful to fight COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: February 12, 2020: With Bulletin N. 65, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, attended a teleconference between G7 Health Ministers on COVID-19 (Countries within the G7 include: Italy, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, USA and UK). The aim of the conference was to share information between Health Ministries of the G7. During the conference, updates were provided on the state of the epidemic in each State and on the measures taken by each State. Possible future scenarios were also examined. Finally, the Ministers discussed the procedures for the exchange of biological material in order to share all the information in the field of scientific research.

description: April 3, 2020: With Bulletin N. 135, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, attended a summit with G7 Health Ministers on COVID-19 (Countries within the G7 include: Italy, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, USA and UK). The aim of the conference was to share information about the COVID-19 health crisis between Health Ministries of the G7. During the conference, updates were provided on the state of the epidemic in each country and on the measures taken by each State. During the meeting, a common problem that emerge was the need to improve the validation of serological tests and the use of the most modern technologies for 'fast tracking'. The Italian Minister said that the G7 countries need a common approach to the same issues and that international collaboration is vital.

description: On the 19 March 2020, the Prefecture of the Region of Grand Est in France published an online article rebutting misinformation about Covid-19 (including scams and fradulent cures) which had appeared online, and reiterating the correct health responses and procedures.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On March 20th, Lyon published an announcement warning against scammers taking advantage of the Covid-19 pandemic, including those selling hand sanitizer at prices higher than the national fixed price. The city "reminds individuals that there does not currently exist any vaccine, food, air purifier, lamp, dietary supplement, or any other product that protects from or cures COVID 19." The announcement also reminded readers that "COVID 19 tests are carried out by health authorities via medical prescription. No other organization or individual is allowed to process these tests."
The announcement warns that purchasing paracetamol online is illegal, and warns against scams of home decontamination procedures, stating that "no home decontamination procedures are scheduled by the government at this time. Those pretending to carry out a mandatory decontamination are unauthorized to do so and are looking to gain access into unsuspecting peoples' houses."
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On April 2, 2020, the French Minister of the Interior confirmed that the digital attestation passes needed for travel outside of the home could not collect personal information. There had been concerns that the information provided was being collected by the government. The government confirmed that the digital attestation only provided the same information as the previous paper form of the attestation. None of the data would be transmitted to government servers and only work locally.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 6, 2020, the French national government issued statements, confirming that a map of dates when lockdown restrictions would be lifted was not from the government. The map was shared on social media and contained official logos of the French Ministry of Health. When contacted for comment, the office of the Prime Minister confirmed that the map was a hoax. The prefecture of Hauts-de-France et du Nord also published a statement on Twitter explaining that the map was fake and asking people not to continue sharing it. They asked that people follow official government accounts for information.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 22, 2020, the French Director General of Health, Jéròme Salomon, made a statement during a press conference advising people that a study suggesting nicotine preventing COVID-19 has not been proven. Although the minister did not rule out the possibility of nicotine preventing COVID-19, he cautioned the public to be mindful of the proven dangers of smoking. He warned people not to use nicotine as a treatment at this time. The Minister of Health, Olivier Véran, made a similar statement advising people not to self-medicate.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 30, 2020, the French government agency, SIG (Service of government information) created a webpage entitled "Desinfox" to combat misinformation ("fake news") about COVID-19. The site was meant to fact check news articles and provide reliable information on the pandemic to citizens. The government said the site would be taken down after the COVID crisis ended.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On May 27, 2020, the French Health Ministry forbade the use of the drug hydroxychloroquine in COVID-19 patients based on new studies showing that it had no benefit and might cause adverse health effects. The use of hydroxychloroquine to prevent COVID-19 had been promoted by high-profile figures.

description: On January 26, 2021, in a press release, INSERM (the French National Institute of Health and Medical Research) published a review of ivermectin's potential as a treatment against COVID-19. Ivermectin is a medication used to treat parasitic infections. Using ivermectin to treat COVID is being promoted online. INSERM concluded that studies performed up to this point are no sufficient to show that ivermectin is able to treat or prevent COVID and recommended against its use.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 2, 2021, the French national government republished information from the Corsica Regional Health Agency on how to combat disinformation related to the COVID-19 pandemic. The government website provides a list of reputable information sources, including links to the French government's coronavirus page, the Ministry of Health, the French Public Health website, the Pasteur Institute, the World Health Organization, the Ministry for Travel, the Ministry for Education, the Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs, and SantéBD (a site that provides comprehensible information about COVID to the public). The government website also provides several graphics addressing common misconceptions about COVID (ex. drinking hot liquid cannot kill the virus, despite claims).
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: March 3, 2020. Both primary and secondary schools have been shut in the Oise department north of Paris and in Brittany, where the main clusters of French cases have emerged, and where two people who have died of the virus lived.  France’s education minister, Jean-Michel Blanquer, said around 120 schools have been ordered to close, most in Brittany and the Oise region north of Paris, which have been hit hard by COVID-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus. Tens of thousands of students were sent home.

description: From March 9, 2020, the prefects of Corsica and Corse-du-Sud in France announced that schools in Ajaccio are closed until March 22, 2020. On March 12, 2020 the prefect of Corse-du-Sud, in conjunction with the rector of the academic region of Corsica, extended the region affected by school closures beyond the Ajaccio city limits, closing additional schools and colleges located in the greater Ajaccio area. All schools within these areas remain closed until Sunday March 22, 2020 UPDATE: On March 12, the geographical target of this policy changed as the prefect of southern Corsica, in conjunction with the rector of the academic region of Corsica, decided on Thursday 12 March to close additional schools and colleges located in the greater Ajaccio area rather than just in the city, until Sunday March 22. UPDATE: On March 12, the geographical target of this policy changed as the prefect of southern Corsica, in conjunction with the rector of the academic region of Corsica, decided on Thursday 12 March to close additional schools and colleges located in the greater Ajaccio area rather than just in the city, until Sunday March 22.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On May 5th 2020, the Mayor of Paris in France announced the city's deconfinement plan highlighting strict sanitary protocols for students returning to school starting the week of May 11th 2020 which would be published on France's Ministry of National Education's website. This policy was implemented in line with France's national deconfinement policy. These measures consist of classrooms being disinfected before reopening, strict schedules put into place at the beginning of school days, if possible separate entrances for student arrivals, no more than 16 pupils in a room of 50 m2, desks should be placed at least one meter apart in classrooms, social distancing during recess, frequent ventilation of rooms every 10 minutes, disinfection of common areas, masks are mandatory for staff, and recommended, but not mandatory for primary school students.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Regular cleaning and sanitary procedures applied to classrooms (e.g. classrooms must be aired out after each class) ,Other conditions not listed above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: From May 11, France is gradually reopening its schools after its lockdown. Pre-schools (maternelles) and primary schools will reopen from May 11, secondary schools will reopen from May 18. Decisions on the reopening of high-schools (lycées) and technical colleges (lycée professionals) will be made in late May. Also, classes are limited to groups of 15 pupils, and attending class will be voluntary.

description: From May 11, France is gradually reopening its schools after its lockdown. Pre-schools (maternelles) and primary schools will reopen from May 11, secondary schools will reopen from May 18. Decisions on the reopening of high-schools (lycées) and technical colleges (lycée professionals) will be made in late May. Also, classes are limited to groups of 15 pupils, and attending class will be voluntary.

description: 18 May, 2020. 8 schools in northern France close due to cases. Schools only began reopening in France last week, but seven public institutions and one private school in Roubaix closed on Monday morning. The decision was made after one child in reception class contracted Covid-19. Local authorities said the most of the affected schools will be able to reopen by May 25. It was not confirmed whether the 70 or so cases were among staff or pupils.

description: On May 19, 2020, the Rectorate of the Ile-de-France region of France with the support of the regional prefect, departmental prefects, state services, ARS (Regional Health Agency) and communities have defined a common protocol for the reopening of schools. The strict health protocol is broken down into 3 stages: 1) Make an inventory of reception, sanitary and logistical conditions in all establishments, 2) Define an educational reception plan and logistics organization and 3) Develop a prioritization plan for audiences based on the possible mobilization of staff.

description: According to the Minister of Education of France, from January 14, 2021, the government would roll out a mass-testing scheme in schools, testing up to one million pupils and teachers each month: "Every time there are three cases (discovered), a screening team will be sent to the premises". In the canteens, pupils in the same class will eat together every day and at the same table. High school pupils in terminale (third and final year) would have to be present “as much as possible”. The government announced that all indoor sports were temporarily suspended. This includes out-of-school activities. First-year university students will be authorised to return to their courses on-site, but with reduced numbers of participants, from January 25th.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

Instead, distance learning for all students will take place from April 6, 2021 until April 9, 2021 before their two week Easter holiday (April 10, 2021 - April 25, 2021).This measure also applies to out-of-school establishments, but does not apply to medico-social structures supporting children with disabilities.

description: On July 28, 2021, the Minister for National Education of France announced a new policy for middle and high schools to be implemented from the start of the new school year on September 2. A four-tier system of restrictions will be in place with controls depending on the incidence of COVID-19. Level 1 (Green): In-person learning at all levels. Level 2 (Yellow): In-person learning at all levels. Level 3 (Orange): In-person learning at primary and middle schools, hybrid learning (alternating distance and in-person learning) in high schools. Level 4 (Red): In-person learning in primary schools, hybrid learning for 50% of 3rd year, all 4th year and high school students. Increasing levels of sanitary requirements, mask-wearing, restrictions on sports, and protocols for contact tracing will be applied at each level.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Following the French National Authority for Health (HAS) recommendations, the French national government announced on the 3rd of December 2020 its Covid-19 vaccination strategy, which applies to all of France: 
- Phase 1 will target individual living in residential accommodations for dependent elderly people (E.H.P.A.D) as well as the staff.
- Phase 2 will target individuals over 75 years old, in the 64-75 age range, healthcare professionals over 50 and/or immunocompromised healthcare professionals.
- Phase 3 will target all the rest of the population, with a focus on individuals between the ages of 50 and 64, as well as individuals working in essential sectors (education,security and services).

description: After the vaccination of an initial 1 million people in January 2021 in France, an additional 14 million at high risk for coronavirus infection will be inoculated beginning in February 2021. France has ordered 200 million doses from different pharmaceutical companies developing vaccines, enough to inoculate 100 million people - more than France's population of just over 66 million. According to the Prime Minister of the country, Jean Castex, vaccination will be voluntary and free of charge.

description: On December 5, 2020, French Prime Minister Jean Castex outlined a national vaccination plan during a news conference late Thursday, in accordance with the High Authority for Health. It will start January 1, 2021 with a free shot to everyone. France has ordered 1 million doses from the three different companies who have vaccine candidates: Pfizer, along with BioNTech, Moderna, both US-based, and AstraZeneca, based in the UK. The 1 million elderly who live in care homes will be the first to receive it, followed by health care workers employed in nursing homes and, importantly, those who transport them, then the elderly population. A second vaccination campaign will follow in February where the vaccine will be given to those older than 75, then 65 to 74 with a co-morbidity, then to those in the age group without. Following that, anyone in the health and medical fields older than 50 will receive the shot. The general population will then receive the vaccine in the spring, from the eldest to the most vulnerable, followed by the remainder of the population.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: From the 2nd of January, French medical staff over 50 will begin to be vaccinated (which had previously been planned for February), to speed up the vaccination roll out. The reason for this is a much slower debut of the vaccination campaign than most other European countries: as of December 31, 2020, only 352 people in France had gotten at least one dose of the vaccine, versus 131,626 in Germany and 944,539 in the U.K., according to data cited by Le Parisien.

description:
Following the French National Authority for Health (HAS) recommendations, the French national government announced on the 3rd of December 2020 its Covid-19 vaccination strategy, which applies to all of France: 
- Phase 1 will target individual living in residential accommodations for dependent elderly people (E.H.P.A.D) as well as the staff.
- Phase 2 will target individuals over 75 years old, in the 64-75 age range, healthcare professionals over 50 and/or immunocompromised healthcare professionals.
- Phase 3 will target all the rest of the population, with a focus on individuals between the ages of 50 and 64, as well as individuals working in essential sectors (education,security and services). UPDATE: Originally, the second phase of the COVID-19 vaccination strategy (vaccinating people having a risk factor, chronic illnesses, etc.) was supposed to be held from February to spring 2021. On January 14 2021, the French national government announced that individuals of all ages that are at high risk of contracting the virus will be allowed to get vaccinated starting from the 18th of January 2020. This will include individuals who have severe medical issues such as cancer, hematological diseases that need chemotherapy treatment, chronic illnesses, organ transplants, transplanted by allogeneic  hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, chronic multiple pathologies and presenting at least two organ failure and Down's syndrome.

description:
First delivery of doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine to France will take place on February 6, 2021. After receiving a European marketing authorization on January 29, 2021, the vaccine developed by the firm AstraZeneca was the subject of a recommendation from the High Authority for Health (HAS). This vaccine is administered in two doses and can prevent severe forms of COVID 19 in people aged 18 and over. At this stage, the HAS recommends this vaccine:
- in people under 65, starting with professionals in the health or medico-social sector, regardless of their age;
- and in people aged 50 to 64, prioritizing those with comorbidities. 
273,600 doses will be distributed from today between 117 establishments, including 7 overseas. The next delivery will take place next week (304,800 doses) .

description:
Following the French National Authority for Health (HAS) recommendations, the French national government announced on the 3rd of December 2020 its Covid-19 vaccination strategy, which applies to all of France: 
- Phase 1 will target individual living in residential accommodations for dependent elderly people (E.H.P.A.D) as well as the staff.
- Phase 2 will target individuals over 75 years old, in the 64-75 age range, healthcare professionals over 50 and/or immunocompromised healthcare professionals.
- Phase 3 will target all the rest of the population, with a focus on individuals between the ages of 50 and 64, as well as individuals working in essential sectors (education,security and services). UPDATE: Originally, Phase 3 (vaccinating professionals in essential sectors, people aged 50 to 64, etc.) was supposed to launch in spring 2021. From the 6th of February 2021, throughout France, vaccination is allowed for all health and social sector professionals, private nurses and firefighters regardless of their age.

- Phase 1 will target individual living in residential accommodations for dependent elderly people (E.H.P.A.D) as well as the staff.
- Phase 2 will target individuals over 75 years old, in the 64-75 age range, healthcare professionals over 50 and/or immunocompromised healthcare professionals.

description:
Since the 12th of February 2021, doctors are allowed to vaccinate their patients between the ages of 50 and 64 years old, including those with severe illnesses, with the Astrazeneca vaccine. 10 vials of the AstraZeneca vaccine will be available at a local pharmacy to doctors willing to vaccinate. Each doctor would need to choose a dispensary between the 15th of February 2021 and the 17th of February 2021. The chosen pharmacy will be working with the doctor perpetually. This process does not require the registration of the practitioner's name and RPPS number in the tele-declaration portal. Volunteer doctors are therefore invited to approach the pharmacy of their choice as soon as possible. UPDATE: Since the 25th of February 2021, doctors that do not exclusively work in hospitals (private doctors and salaried doctors) have the possibility to vaccinate their 50 to 64-year-old patients with the AstraZeneca vaccine. These patients should have diseases that put them at severe risk of catching Covid-19. This decision, made in accordance with the French National Authority for Health (HAS), was released on the 2nd of February 2021. From March 2, doctors can
now also offer vaccination with the AstraZeneca vaccine:
- to their patients aged 65 to 74 when they have comorbidities with risk factors for forms severe from COVID. 
- to all their patients aged 75 and over.

description: According to the decree of March 4, 2021, midwives in France can prescribe vaccines to any person, including women, those close to pregnant women and children during the postnatal period, with the exception of people with a history of an anaphylactic reaction to one of the components of these vaccines or having presented an anaphylactic reaction during the first injection. Community pharmacists, mutualist pharmacies and mining emergency pharmacies can prescribe vaccines to any person, except pregnant women, people with a hemostasis disorder and people with a history of anaphylactic reactions.

description:
On the 15th of February 2021, the French national government delivered 9190 doses of Pfizer vaccines to the island of The Reunion (an overseas territory of France).The French government decided to accelerate its vaccination programme in The Reunion and is looking to deliver 30420 additional doses before March. UPDATE: On the 25th of March 2021, French Health Minister Olivier Véran and Minister of Overseas Territories Sébastien Lecornu announced that they will be supplying some overseas territories with additional vaccine doses:
-3500 doses for Réunion Island, Martinique, Guadeloupe and Mayotte on the week of the 25th of March.
-5850 doses for Réunion Island on the week of the 5th of April.
-6000 doses for New Caledonia,Guyana and French Polynesia. 
-18000 doses for Wallis-et-Futuna. 
-9600 doses for Sainte-Pierre and Miquelon.

description:
"In accordance with decree n ° 2021-325 of March 26, 2021, the following groups below can participate in the vaccination campaign by administering vaccines in vaccination centers around France: 
- students in their 3rd cycle of medical school.
- students in their 3rd cycle of pharmacy provided that they have followed either the
theory and practice relating to vaccination as part of their course.
- individuals studying in the field of healthcare provided that they have followed either the theory and practice relating to vaccination as part of their cours
- students in their 2nd or 3rd cycles of dentistry, in the presence of a doctor or nurse. They also need to have gone training, certified by healthcare professionals trained in vaccine administration. 
- students in their 2nd cycle of medical school or pharmacy. 
- students in their first cycle of medical school having completed their nursing internship, in the presence of a doctor or nurse. They also need to have training certified by healthcare professionals trained in vaccine administration.

description: On March 17, the European Commission has made the proposal for a “digital green certificate” whose objective is to allow, in a secure manner, the movement of people between the countries of the European Union. France is fully in line with this approach and is launching “TousAntiCovid Carnet” with test and vaccination certificates that can be verified at national level, then by the other countries of the European Union, and terminates outside the borders of the European Union. The French Government is offering 3 types of certificates: the negative test certificate, the recovery from Covid-19 and the vaccination certificate.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On the 15th of February 2021, the French national government delivered 9190 doses of Pfizer vaccines to the island of The Reunion (an overseas territory of France).The French government decided to accelerate its vaccination programme in The Reunion and is looking to deliver 30420 additional doses before March. UPDATE: In order to promote the vaccination campaign in the French Overseas territories, Sébastien Lecornu, Minister of Overseas Territories, and Olivier Véran, Minister of Solidarity and Health, expand the vaccination campaign targets in some territories: 

- In Guadeloupe, Martinique, Guyana, Saint-Barthélémy, Saint-Martin, Saint-Pierre and Miquelon and Wallis and Futuna, vaccination is open to all people over 18 years old.
- In Mayotte, vaccination is open to all people over 16.
- In Reunion, from May 3, in addition to anyone over the age of 55, vaccination will also be open to people over 50 and to at risk people aged 45.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_vac_purchase: Preorder with the option of expanding the order
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
The vaccination campaign enters a new phase from May 1, 2021 in France: all people over 18 suffering from one or more co-morbidities as defined by the Ministry of Solidarity and Health and in accordance with the recommendations of the High Authority for Health, is able to get the Moderna or Pfizer vaccine. 

The list of comorbidities associated with a risk of severe form of Covid-19, defined by the Ministry of Solidarity and Health, following the recommendations of the Haute Autorité de Santé is as follows: cardiovascular pathologies; types 1 and 2 diabetes; chronic respiratory pathologies liable to decompensate during a viral infection; chronic renal failure; obesity with body mass index ≥30; cancer or malignant hemopathy; chronic liver disease, especially cirrhosis; congenital or acquired immunosuppression; major sickle cell syndrome or history of splenectomy; neurological pathologies; psychiatric disorders; dementia.

People aged 18 to 49 who suffer from comorbidities will therefore now be able to make an appointment at a vaccination according to the usual procedures in order to be vaccinated with the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccines.

UPDATE: On 28 October, 2020, president Emmanuel Macron announced that the curfew in Île-de-France will be extended until 1 December.

The curfew will now start at 6pm instead of 8pm, as in the rest of the country, in a further 8 departments, as they were added to the 15 departments, where this rule has already applied since January 2. The new departments subject to an earlier curfew are primarily in the east of the country, including Bas-Rhin, Haut-Rhin and Cote d'Or, as well as the central one of Cher.

description: On the 24 Febraury 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France made a press release detailing a system of health monitoring for returned travellers. The management system targed returned travellers from the Veneto and Lombardy regions of Italy, mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore and South Korea. If returned travellers displayed any symptoms, they were required to contact a centre for assessment and possible testing, and if confirmed ARS staff would trace close contacts. Positive cases were then instructed to self-isolate for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From March 31, 2020, until April 15, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health mandated that it is forbidden, for any cruise ship, with or without passengers, to call, stop or anchor in French internal waters and territorial sea, unless otherwise permitted by the representative of the competent State. This policy does not apply to:
-maritime transport of internal security forces or emergency services and other means essential to the protection of the population, as well as of the armed forces essential to the ongoing missions of the ministry responsible for defence
-the reception of ships in difficulty or to ships having rescued people at sea
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From March 30, 2020, in France, for ships making international connections or connections of more than two hours, passengers must present to the maritime carrier, when they board, one or more documents to justify the reason for their trip, accompanied by a statement on the honor of this motif. description:
From May 11, 2020 in France, any movement of a person leading them both to leave a perimeter defined by a radius of 100 kilometers from their place of residence and to leave the department in which the latter is located is prohibited except travel for the following reasons:
(1) Travel for work that cannot be postponed. 
(2) Travel to school or other educational establishments by a student or thier parent or carer and necessary trips to get to school exams or competitions.
(3) Travel for medical appointements that cannot be provided remotely or closer to home;
(4) Travel for urgent family reasons, and for the assistance of vulnerable people, people with disabilities and for childcare;
(5) Travel to report to law enforcement
(6) Travel to report to administrative court or judicial authority
(7) Travel at the request of the administrative authority
The department prefect is allowed to adopt more restrictive travel conditions within a department when local circumstances so require. People traveling under an exeption must bring with them, during their travels, a declaration indicating the reason for the trip accompanied, documents justifying this reason, and proof of place of residence.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From March 15, 2020, the Franco-German border restrictions will be strengthened in both directions. France has officially announced that it will strengthen controls at its border with Germany and limit border crossings to what is strictly necessary, allowing cross-border people and the transport of goods to pass. Beginning May 13th, 2020, the Franco-German border restrictions will remain in action until June 15, 2020 and new exemptions come into force for entry into French territory. Separated spouses are now allowed to cross the border to find each other. Border crossings justified by the exercise of the right of custody, visit or accommodation of a child or the pursuit of schooling, as well as the visit to a parent in an EHPAD or to a child in a specialized institution, are now also allowed. In addition, the documentation required to cross the Franco-German border will be simplified. UPDATE: new exemptions come into force for entry into French territory. An end date was also added.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On June 12, 2020, in France, the foreign minister Jean-Yves Le Drian and the minister of the interior Christophe Castaner announce that from June 15, 2020, the travel restrictions and border closures in place since March 18, 2020, will remain for all countries except EU Member States as well as Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the Vatican. From July 1, 2020, France will start to reopen the borders to some non-Schengen countries. UPDATE: The french secretary of state responsible for tourism announced a new exception to the travel restrictions starting August 8, 2020. Foreign nationals in relationships with French citizens will now be allowed to enter the French territory. To prove their relationship, they need to show proof of their partners French nationality, but also proof that the relationship is lasting and sentimental, for example by common bank accounts or invioces, rental lease agreements, passport stamps of frequent visits to the country.

They are further oblieged to isolate for seven days and if aged older than eleven, take another PCR test after.

description: From 1 March 2021, residents of Andorra and visitors to the French departments of Pyrenees Orientales and Ariege will be exempt from taking a test (PCR or TMA) when entering France. This exemption only applies to trips of less than 24 hours. Prior to this, travellers arriving in France from a European country, including Andorra, are required to provide a negative PCR or TMA test result of less than 72 hours for all those over 11 years old.

description:
Starting March 25, 2020, the validity of residence documents (long-stay visas, residence permits, temporary residence permits, permit application receipts and asylum application certificates) are extended for a period of 90 days. The period of extension applies to the validity of residence permits that expire between March 16 and May 15.

description: 02.28.2020 in France, the French National Government has announced that for unvaccinated or not fully vaccinated people, isolation is 10 days with the possibility of carrying out an antigen or RT-PCR test to lift isolation on Day 7. Isolation can be lifted if the test result is negative and in the absence of clinical signs of infection for 48 hours. If the test performed on D7 is positive, or in the absence of this test, isolation is for a total of 10 days (no new test to be performed on D10).

description: 03.10.2020 in France, the French National Government has announced that a new innovation "vaccinobus" is going to meet the people over-70s in rural areas for vaccination against Covid-19. The goal of the vaccinobus is to reach the most isolated people and monitor the health condition of people in isolated areas or patients in their state of health does not allow to move.

description: On March 18, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Higher Education, Research, and Innovation extended the powers of university health services to enable them to carry out health monitoring of isolated students in university residences or the staff of these residences. Higher education establishments, regional health agencies, and local health centers will collaborate to identify isolated students occupying student residences as well as the staff of these residences affected by covid-19, ensure their medical follow-up, and implement the support methods with regard to acts of daily life.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: From March 21, 2020, in France, the French High Council for Public Health has proposed a procedure for monitoring contact cases: contact persons at risk, regardless of their vaccination status, should no longer isolate themselves. They must carry out a test (TAG, RT-PCR or self-test) on Day + 2 of the notification of the contact status, and strictly apply barrier measures including wearing a mask. They should also limit their contacts as far as possible, in particular with people at risk of serious illness, and give preference to teleworking, if applicable.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: 04.28.2020 in France, the French Prime Minister has stated that the “brigades” of people will be created who are responsible to trace contacts of people who test positive for Covid-19 after confinement ends, to help contain further spread of the virus. "Prime minister Edouard Philippe made the announcement as part of his speech on Tuesday April 28. He said: “[We want to] protect, test, isolate. In each department, we will have brigades whose job it is to compile a list of contacts, and to call them, to invite them to be tested, telling them where to go for a test, and then to check that these tests have indeed been done.”

description: 05.11.2020 in France, creation of a centralized national system of information screening, called SI-DEP. The minister of health is the only one in charge of it. "L'assistance publique-Hôpitaux de Paris" handles it on a daily basis. This system aims to centralize the screening results of COVID-19 in order that they're available for the organizations in charge of establishing the persons who have been in contact with COVID-19 cases, so that they may realise sanitary polls in case of group cases in order to break the contamination chains, to give information, to follow and accompany people concerned, and to ease the epidemiological monitoring at both national and local level and the research on the virus as the means to struggle with its spread

description: On March 23 2020, the region of Ile-De-France in France has created a 10 million euros to help medical practitioners with emergency medical equipment, the region will grant up to 5000 euros by practitioner and 30 000 euros by doctor's office. This aid can only be ask for until September 30 2020 .

description: From March 17, 2020 in France, the Minister of Solidarity and Health has sanctioned the use of army transports and army medical personnel to assist in the distribution of covid-19 patients between different health establishments and maintain care during transport. UPDATE: On March 23, 2020, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health stated that this policy, originally in effect until further notice, is in effect until April 15, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In France, on March 24, 2020, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health announced it was mobilizing 40,000 social work students who are not currently on an internship to form a social reserve to actively contribute to the maintenance of social and medico-social action. They will be placed in institutions housing the most fragile or vulnerable citizens, including elderly care institutions, special needs institutions, child protection institutions, emergency accommodation centers, child care and other centers.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The region of Pays de la Loire is encouraging individuals in possession of an excess amount of masks are to hand them in to the nearest pharmacy if the individual has less than 500 masks, to call a government hotline or email a specific email address if they have more than 500 masks, or contact the ministry of health if they have more than 200,000 masks. If the masks have not expired, the individual may receive a receipt of compensation. The prefecture makes this policy on the basis that 'masks are a precious resource', with the intention to distribute these masks to surgeons and other healthcare workers.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 24, several hundred migrants were evacuated early this morning in Aubervilliers in Seine-Saint-Denis by the police after an order from the prefect of the Île-de-France region of France. Due to a severe lack of hygiene, the evecuation should help the fight against the spread of the virus.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On March 24 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France announced that as part of regional efforts to procure surgical masks, local companies had capable of mask production had been identified and ordered to redirct their production towards masks. As of March 24 2020, 14 enterprises had been identified in Vosges, Aube, Moselle, Bas-Rhin and Haut-Rhin. 3 factories had already commenced mask production and 11 more were awaiting approval. Furthermore, a "Mask Cell" had been activated by the ARS and the Regional Council of Grand Est to distribute masks as efficiently as possible to those who needed them.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 24, the municipality of Paris announced a donation of 1.5 million masks for hospitals in Paris, in addition to 2 million masks already made available.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: From March 25, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health authorized doctors to prescribe, dispense, and administer hydroxychloroquine and the lopinavir / ritonavir combination to patients with covid-19, in the health establishments which take care of them, as well as at home for the continuation of their treatment if their condition allows it the initial prescriber authorizes it.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 25 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France announced that a medical train staffed by a team from Grand Est would start operating that day. The train was made avaiable from the French national railway company, SNCF, and could transport 4 patients per carriage. A medical team consisting of an ICU doctor, one intern, one anaesthetic nurse and three generalist nurses would work onboard the train. This policy was undertaken in accordance with the French national policy of relocation of Covid patients from hospitals in most-affected regions to less-affected regions.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 25 March 2020, it was announced that The Ministry of Solidarity and Health of France is now funding 11 covid-related projects up to a maximum of nearly 9 million euros. These projects span much of the health research continuum, from diagnosis to treatment to the psychological impact of the epidemic, and concern both patients and caregivers.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 26, 2020, as part of their campaign to allow women who are victims of domestic violence to alert pharmacists that they need help, the French Ministry of the Interior announced that women can use the code "Mask 19". The code allows the women to communicate with the pharmacists without letting their partner to know what is going on. The pharmicist can then alert the police.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 13 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France announced that both public and private hospitals throughout Grand Est had been put on alert to receive Covid-positive patients, and Intensive Care Unit (ICU) capacity was also being increased with an ultimate goal of a 60% increase in capacity. UPDATE: On March 26 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France annouced that 1000 ICU beds were operational throughout Grand Est.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 21 2020, the the Regional Health Agency of the Grand Est region of France announced that healthcare students throughout the region had been mobilised to support health staff in Grand Est. UPDATE: On March 26 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France annouced that 6,600 student nurses and 1,600 student nursing assistants had been mobilised across the region to assist medical professionals. It was also announced that student nurses and student nursing assistants would now be compensated for their work. Under this new policy, student nurses will recieve 1,400 euros per month and student nursing assistants 1,000 euro per month (normally, student nurses and nursing assistants recieved allowances but no pay for their placements). This policy was undertaken with the agreement of the French Ministry of Labour.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On the 27 March 2020, the Regional Health Agency of the Grand Est region of France announced that several policies were being proposed to provide psychological support for aged care workers. These included: the mobilisation of the L'Espace de Réflexion Ethique Grand Est (Space of Ethical Reflection of Grand Est) which set up an ethics support unit, a solicitation of services of the region's medico-psychological centres, the use of a national online support network for health workers, and the solicitation of psychologists working within health structures.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On the 27 March 2020, the Regional Health Agency of the Grand Est region of France released information about policies designed to reinforce staff in aged care facilities. The on-call system of state graduate nurses was used to cover night shifts, nursing staff were pooled in territories, and student nurses were used to fill staffing gaps.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On the 27 March 2020, the Regional Health Agency of the Grand Est region of France announced the establishment of a 24hr per day, 7 day per week on-call medical assistance service for aged care facilities in the region, with the objective of providing physicians working in aged care with support for geriatric medicine. Geriatric medicine and infectious disease experts will provide information for the service.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities,Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: On the 27 March 2020, the Regional Health Agency of the Grand Est region of France announced new policies surrounding supplies to aged care facilities. Extra health equipment was to be mobillised for aged care facilities from their first positive Covid-19 case. The Regional Health Agency would also be in regular contact with aged care facilities to anticipate shortages of PPE to anticipate any shortages.

description: From March 28 2020 until April 15, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has announced that pharmacies authorized to dispense drugs to the public may dispense medicines based on paracetamol in an injectable form within the framework of their marketing authorization on presentation of a prescription from any doctor bearing the words “Prescription in within the framework of covid-19 ”, to allow the management of fever and pain in patients affected or likely to be affected by the SARS-CoV-2 virus and whose clinical condition warrants it.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description: From March 28 2020 until April 15, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has announced that pharmacies that are authorized to dispense drugs to the public may dispense Rivotril® in injectable form on presentation of a medical prescription bearing the words “Prescription Outside Marketing Authorization in the context of of covid-19 ” for the care of patients affected or likely to be affected by the SARS-CoV-2 virus whose clinical condition justifies it.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 25 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France announced that a medical train staffed by a team from Grand Est would start operating that day. The train was made avaiable from the French national railway company, SNCF, and could transport 4 patients per carriage. A medical team consisting of an ICU doctor, one intern, one anaesthetic nurse and three generalist nurses would work onboard the train. This policy was undertaken in accordance with the French national policy of relocation of Covid patients from hospitals in most-affected regions to less-affected regions. This policy was undertaken in accordance with the French national policy of relocation of Covid patients from hospitals in most-affected regions to less-affected regions.

Of the 5 million masks, 2 million were sent to services such as aged care and disability care, and 3 million were sent to healthcare workers.

description: On the 1 April 2020, the Regional Health Agency of the Grand Est region of France announced the decision to create specific accommodation for Covid patients (without serious symptoms) who could not isolate at home due to extenuating factors (for example: co-morbidity risks, no possibility of isolation) and homeless people. Appropriate accommodation was to be identified by the Prefects of Departments, and the Regional Health Agency was to provide provide support if necessary. Several of these centres were also operated by NGOs - such as the Red Cross.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: Homeless population,Other population not specifed above
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From April 2, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has announced that in the event that it is impossible to supply pharmaceutical medicines for human use to patients, medicinal products for veterinary use with a similar therapeutic ail, of the same active substance, the same strength and the same route of administration, can be prescribed, prepared, dispensed and administered in a hospital environment. The list of these drugs and their active ingredients and their conditions of preparation and use are set by the National Agency for the Safety of Medicines and health products and published on its website.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 3 2020, the Île-de-France region of France decided it will grant exceptional individual regional aid to all nursing students enrolled in training institutes in the Île-de-France region and who contribute, during their internship, to the management of the health crisis.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Starting from April 3, 2020, in Paris, France, a center (a highschool boarding school) for the isolation of the vulnerable people was created in order to help decrease the crowding of COVID-19 cases in hospitals.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On March 25 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France announced that a medical train staffed by a team from Grand Est would start operating that day. The train was made avaiable from the French national railway company, SNCF, and could transport 4 patients per carriage. A medical team consisting of an ICU doctor, one intern, one anaesthetic nurse and three generalist nurses would work onboard the train. This policy was undertaken in accordance with the French national policy of relocation of Covid patients from hospitals in most-affected regions to less-affected regions. UPDATE: On April 3 2020, a medical train was used to evacuate 24 patients from hospitals in the Grand Est region of France (in Strasbourg, Colmar, Saverne, Sélestat and Haguenau) to the Nouvelle-Aquitaine region of France. This was the final medical evacuation by train of patients from Grand Est to other regions on France. This policy was undertaken in accordance with the French national policy of relocation of Covid patients from hospitals in most-affected regions to less-affected regions.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 4, 2020, France announced additional provisions and principles of action in order to support people with disabilities, including to reinforce setups and real-time monitoring of the development of the epidemic in the disability sector, strengthen preventive measures in establishments supporting people with disabilities, not to leave establishments and services alone to deal with covid-19 cases, to anticipate and organize treatment at the hospital when necessary, to strengthen the continuity of medico-social support during the duration of the epidemic, and to take the greatest care in identifying the respite needs of carers exposed to a risk of physical and mental exhaustion, as well as support needs of isolated people.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 1st, 2020, French secretary of economy, Agnès Pannier-Runacher, announced that the Direction générale de la concurrence, de la consommation et de la répression des fraudes (DGCCRF) is going to make surveys about masks to guarantee access to good quality masks at reasonable prices, and make sure claims about them are true. French government decided to regulate the price of masks for use unique type of surgery and to implement a monitoring of the prices of masks. The DGCCRF will monitor compliance with regulated prices and monitor the other prices. The maximum price per mask will be 0.95 cents of euro, after taxes.

description: 02.26.2020 in France, the Ministry for Solidarity and Health has stated that "Extra resources have been allocated for testing for potential cases of coronavirus and the testing capacity has been multiplied by three. description: 03.28.2020 in France, the French National Government has announced that for patients diagnosed in hospital or with signs of severity, the tests will be performed in hospitals. For other patients meeting the screening criteria, it is possible to be tested in laboratories in town, after contact with the attending physician and medical prescription. The samples will be taken at home. In no case should you go directly to the biological laboratories, but call them beforehand, and only if you have a medical prescription, because there is a great risk of infecting other patients, especially the most fragile

Symptomatic people, health workers, at-home carers, and health students were eligible to be tested, and had to prevent either a student card, professional membership card (for health workers), proof of health insurance, proof of employment as an at-home carer, or a medical certificate order to be eligible for the testing.

description: 04.02.2021, The Ministry of Solidarity and Health has announced that in case if a child over 12 years old is unvaccinated and has a positive case, the following procedure should be implemented: isolation for a period of 10 days after the date of the onset of signs or the date of collection of the positive test (10 full days). Lifting of isolation is possible on Day 7 with a negative antigen or RT-PCR test result (and in the absence of clinical signs of infection for 48 hours). If the test carried out on D7 is positive or if this test is not carried out, isolation is for a total of 10 days (no new test to be carried out on D10).

description: 06.18.2021 in France, the French National Government has announced that PCR testing appears generally available: Virological tests (RT-PCR) : they make it possible to determine whether a person is a carrier of the virus at the time of the test, thanks to a nasal or salivary sample. The result is usually available within 24 hours.

description: From July 7, 2021, unless they are of a medical nature, PCR and antigen tests for Covid-19 screening cost money for foreign tourists coming to France and not residing on the national territory. They must spend a minimum of € 43.89 for a PCR test, € 22 for an antigen test.

description: On July 12, 2021, the President of France has announced the end of the systematic free testing for Covid-19 that comes into force on October 15, 2021. RT-PCR, antigen tests and supervised self-tests will no longer be automatically covered 100% by the Health Insurance.

description: France, Hauts-de-France, March 18th, 2020. The government is providing increased access to soap and water in areas with large migrant populations. In the Calais district, the government has installed soap dispensers near water sources, and is also distributing 150 to 200 jugs of water each day. In the commune of Grande-Synthe, a water tank and a drum of liquid soap were installed at the end of February 2020 near private buildings known to be occupied by migrants. The sites, which are operational 7 days a week, are supervised to ensure social distancing during the hand-washing process.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From March 19, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Soldidarity and Health is mandating that all bus and train operators disinfect and clean each vehicle or train car at least once a day. In the event of non-compliance with these hygiene measures, a ban may be placed on transport service on all the lines concerned.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Starting March 19, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has mandated the following hygiene restrictions for taxis and transport cars with a driver:
- The vehicle must be constantly ventilated.
- The driver must clean and disinfect the vehicle at least once a day.

description:
"Order of 19 March 2020 supplementing the order of 14 March 2020 Addressing the Spread of the Covid-19 Virus" by the Ministry of Solidarity and Health states that from March 20, 2020, for the conduct of freight operations, hygiene and distancing measures, called "barriers", defined at the national level, must be observed by drivers of 
transportation as well as personnel from the loading or unloading sites. If not provided with a water point, these places are provided with hydro-alcoholic gel.

description:
From March 27, 2020 in France until June 22, 2020, the Minister of Territorial Cohesion and Relations with Local Authorities announced the following temporary exemptions for funeral operators from various funeral law provision in light of covid-19: 
- the transport of the body of a deceased person before and after being put in the coffin can be carried out without prior declaration (declaration must be sent to the mayor no later than one month after the end of this policy)
- The deadlines for burial or cremation may be waived without the prior consent of the prefect to the extent strictly necessary (declaration must be sent to the prefect specifying the delay period implemented no later than 15 days after the burial or cremation)
- the authorization to close the coffin can be transmitted by the registrar to the funeral operator in a dematerialized manner
- The transport of bodies before and after being put in the coffin can be provided by vehicles, acquired or rented by authorized funeral operators."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On the 27 March 2020, the French Department of the Economy, Finances and Revival annouced new hygeine guidelines regarding postal delivery procedures. Warehouses were instructed to maximise the size of deliveries in order to prevent multiple deliveries, and delivery personnel were instructed to knock or phone occupants and leave the delivery on the doorstep. People receiving postal deliveries were instructed to wait before opening the door to allow the delivery personnel to stand back. One metre of distance was ordered to be maintained at all times, and at all stages of the process (packing, sorting and delivery) hygeine measures such as hand-washing were to be maintained. This policy was aimed at postal workers, packing and warehouse workers, and people who recieve postal deliveries.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Asylum/refugee seekers,Domestically abused people,Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable),Other population not specifed above

description:
On 31 May 2020, the French national government announces that: I. - Any operator of public or private collective road passenger transport by coach or bus, or guided or rail transport, shall inform passengers of the hygiene measures [...], by means of audible announcements and by means of a display in the areas accessible to the public and assigned to public passenger transport and onboard each vehicle or rolling stock.
II. - The manager of the spaces assigned to public passenger transport shall provide access to a water and soap point or hydro-alcoholic gel for passengers.
III. - In the vehicles mentioned in I of article 21 (private public transport services for persons; private or public transport services using vehicles with fewer than nine seats, excluding the driver; vehicles used for carpooling; social transport services): 
1° A notice reminding the passengers of the hygiene measures [...] is put up inside the vehicle ;
2° For vehicles with two or more rows of rear seats, hydro-alcoholic gel is made available to passengers
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 14th 2020 the RATP (Régie Autonome des Transports Parisiens) announced that, as of March 15th, transit lines throughout Paris and the Île-de-France region of France will run less often due to a shortage of staff. This will reduce travel within the region and the reason for this change is the need for parents to stay home because of school closures related to COVID-19.

description: On March 14th 2020 the RATP (Régie Autonome des Transports Parisiens) announced that, as of March 15th, transit lines throughout Paris and the Île-de-France region of France will run less often due to a shortage of staff. This will reduce travel within the region and the reason for this change is the need for parents to stay home because of school closures related to COVID-19. UPDATE: On March 24th 2020 it was announced that public transport in the Parisian region of France would be significantly reduced as of March 26th 2020. 50 metro stations will be closed, the metro and RER (Réseau Express Régional) will run from 6h-22h, and lines will operate at only 50% because of the COVID-19 situation.

description: Announced on March 22, 2020  French authorities stated the cancelation of all flights from mainland France to overseas territories, including Martinique, Guadeloupe, Mayotte, La Réunion, Saint-Martin, and Saint-Barthelemy, from Tuesday, March 23, 2020 until April 15, 2020 amid the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. Travel between those islands will also be prohibited, unless for family reasons or health emergency, which must be proven to the relevant authorities before boarding any flight.

description: Restrictions on entering Metropolitan France and territorial communities announced April 7, 2020. All travelers are required, as of April 8, 2020, at midnight, to fill out and carry with them the following travel certificates according to their situation: Return to Metropolitan France or home to a French territorial community; travelling throught France to return to their residence. Foreigners with residence permit, including long-sttary visa can enter France. Validity of documents got extended for 3 months. In limited cases, foreigners with short-term visa may be authorised to enter.

description: In Corsica from May 11 until June 2, residents of Corsica will be allowed to travel freely within public spaces and use public transportation as long as they do not exceed a distance of 100 km from their home. Journey's over 100 km will require an attestation form and are only allowed for imperative family or personal reasons. Wearing a mask is mandatory, and social distancing measures must be respected.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On June 1st 2020 the national government of France announced that the Île-de-France region would be entering the orange zone as of June 2nd 2020. The change to orange zone entails the reopening of internal borders, with travel of 100km or more now allowed in the region. This change occured after the national government put a ban on all travel at the beginning of the pandemic in March 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On March 14th 2020 the RATP (Régie Autonome des Transports Parisiens) announced that, as of March 15th, transit lines throughout Paris and the Île-de-France region of France will run less often due to a shortage of staff. This will reduce travel within the region and the reason for this change is the need for parents to stay home because of school closures related to COVID-19. UPDATE: On June 1st 2020 the national government of France announced that RATP (Régie Autonome des Transports Parisiens) traffic will be increased throughout Paris and the Île-de-France region as of June 2nd 2020. Metro traffic will be back to 100% and all traffic in general will resume to 90% of its usual amount.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From May 11, 2020 in France, President Macron and the Minister of Solidarity and Health have restricted internal travel without a permission slip to within a 100km radius from a person's place of residence. Trips outside of this perimeter are prohibited, except for the following reasons:(1) Travel for work that cannot be postponed. (2) Travel to school or other educational establishments by a student or thier parent or carer and necessary trips to get to school exams or competitions.(3) Travel for medical appointements that cannot be provided remotely or closer to home;(4) Travel for urgent family reasons, and for the assistance of vulnerable people, people with disabilities and for childcare;(5) Travel to report to law enforcement(6) Travel to report to administrative court or judicial authority(7) Travel at the request of the administrative authorityPeople traveling under an exception must bring with them, during their travels, a declaration indicating the reason for the trip, documents justifying this reason, and proof of place of residence. The department prefect is allowed to adopt more restrictive travel conditions within a department when local circumstances so require. UPDATE: On May 28, 2020 in France, the Prime Minister announced that starting June 2, 2020, the internal border restriction on trips longer than 100 km from the home will be lifted.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
"Since June 22, 2020, are prohibited, unless they are based on an overriding personal or family reason, an emergency health reason or a professional reason that cannot be postponed, flights between, of on the one hand, Guyana, Mayotte, French Polynesia, New Caledonia or Wallis and Futuna and, on the other hand, any point in the territory of the Republic.

For flights from or to French Polynesia and New Caledonia, depending on local circumstances, the State representative is empowered to complete the list of reasons that justify the trips.

Anyone wishing to benefit from one of these derogatory grounds must present, when boarding, the document (s) justifying this, as well as a declaration of honor for this reason"
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
"Starting July 10, 2020, the prefect of a department can, for certain hours, limit the spaces and vehicles of public transport to individuals with specific motives. 
These motives include:
(1) travel from and to work or for other professional reasons
(2) travel from and to school, including accompanying others 
(3) travel for health consultations
(4) travel for compelling family reasons, for the assistance of vulnerable people, for respite and support for disabled people and for childcare
(5) travel to report to the policy/a judicial authority
(6) travel to court
(7) travel related to a change of residence/acquisition of rental estate that cannot be deferred"
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From March 19, 2020 until March 31, 2020 in France, in accordance with the national lockdown, movement outside of the home is prohibited except for the following reasons: 
(1) Journeys between home and work that cannot be postponed.
(2) Travel to purchase basic necessities such as groceries.
(3) Travel for health reasons
(4) Travel for compelling family reasons, for the assistance of vulnerable people or for childcare.
(5) Short trips, close to home, related to the individual physical activity (exclusion team sports) and the needs of pets. 
(6) Travel to report to law enforcement.
(7) Travel to report to administrative or judicial authorities.
(8) Travel at the request of the administrative authority.
Local government officials may further restrict movement if local conditions require. People traveling outside of the home for these exceptions must bring documentation justifying their movements fall within the scope of these exceptions. Violation of limits on moving outside one's home, failure to bring documentation justifying an authorized trip, and violation of additional local restrictions where applicable will be punished with a fine of 135 euros on a first offense and 375 euros on the second offense.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
