description:
"From March 23, 2020 until March 31, 2020 in France, in accordance with the national lockdown, movement outside of the home is prohibited except for the following reasons:
  (1) Journeys between home and work that cannot be postponed.
  (2) Travel to purchase basic necessities such as groceries.
  (3) Travel for medical appointments that cannot be completed through video meetings
  (4) Travel for compelling family reasons, for the assistance of vulnerable people and for childcare;
  (5) Short trips, close to home, related to the individual physical activity (excluding team sports) and the needs of pets. These trips are limited to one hour per day, within a maximum radius of one kilometer around the home, and prohibit any proximity to other people except people from the same home.
(6) Travel to report to law enforcement.
(7) Travel to report to administrative or judicial authority
(8) Travel at the request of the adiminstrive authority.
Local government officals may further restrict movement if local conditions require. People traveling outside of the home for these exceptions must bring documentation justifying their movements fall within the scope of these exceptions. "Violations of lockdown measures are punishable by a €135 fine, a €200 fine in the case of recidivism within 15 days and up to six months’ imprisonment and a €3,750 fine if more than three violations are reported within 30 days."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

These trips are limited to one hour per day, within a maximum radius of one kilometer around the home, and prohibit any proximity to other people except people from the same home.
(6) Travel to report to law enforcement.
(7) Travel to report to administrative or judicial authority
(8) Travel at the request of the adiminstrive authority.
Local government officals may further restrict movement if local conditions require. People traveling outside of the home for these exceptions must bring documentation justifying their movements fall within the scope of these exceptions. "Violations of lockdown measures are punishable by a €135 fine, a €200 fine in the case of recidivism within 15 days and up to six months’ imprisonment and a €3,750 fine if more than three violations are reported within 30 days." UPDATE: On April 14, 2020 this policy was extended a second time until May 11, 2020 by the Ministry of Solidarity and Health

description:
On May 7 2020, the French government announced that lockdown conditions would remain in place in the Department of Mayotte until a decision was made on May 14 2020 (the rest of France would be progressively released from lockdown after May 11 2020). 
These conditions were: movement outside of the home is prohibited except for the following reasons:
  (1) Journeys between home and work that cannot be postponed.
  (2) Travel to purchase basic necessities such as groceries.
  (3) Travel for medical appointments that cannot be completed through video meetings
  (4) Travel for compelling family reasons, for the assistance of vulnerable people and for childcare;
  (5) Short trips, close to home, related to the individual physical activity (excluding team sports) and the needs of pets. These trips are limited to one hour per day, within a maximum radius of one kilometer around the home, and prohibit any proximity to other people except people from the same home.
(6) Travel to report to law enforcement.
(7) Travel to report to administrative or judicial authority
(8) Travel at the request of the administrative authority.
People travelling outside of the home for these exceptions must bring documentation justifying their movements fall within the scope of these exceptions. Violations of lockdown measures are punishable by fines or imprisonment.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
"From March 23, 2020 until March 31, 2020 in France, in accordance with the national lockdown, movement outside of the home is prohibited except for the following reasons:
  (1) Journeys between home and work that cannot be postponed.
  (2) Travel to purchase basic necessities such as groceries.
  (3) Travel for medical appointments that cannot be completed through video meetings
  (4) Travel for compelling family reasons, for the assistance of vulnerable people and for childcare;
  (5) Short trips, close to home, related to the individual physical activity (excluding team sports) and the needs of pets. These trips are limited to one hour per day, within a maximum radius of one kilometer around the home, and prohibit any proximity to other people except people from the same home.
(6) Travel to report to law enforcement.
(7) Travel to report to administrative or judicial authority
(8) Travel at the request of the adiminstrive authority.
Local government officals may further restrict movement if local conditions require. People traveling outside of the home for these exceptions must bring documentation justifying their movements fall within the scope of these exceptions. "Violations of lockdown measures are punishable by a €135 fine, a €200 fine in the case of recidivism within 15 days and up to six months’ imprisonment and a €3,750 fine if more than three violations are reported within 30 days." UPDATE: On May 7, 2020, in France, the Prime Minister, the Minister of Interior, the Minister of Health, the Minister of Transport, the Minister of the National Education and the Minister of the Economy and Finance, the Minister of Labour presented the roadmap of the release of lockdown in France. The nationwide lockdown would end in all departments (both red and green) except Mayotte on May 11 2020, but red departments would have stronger restrictions on schools and government services/businesses than green departments. Vulnerable populations (such as elderly people and those with chronic illnesses) were released from lockdown but Prime Minister Phillipe advised these populations 'act with caution.' This announcement ended the nationwide lockdown announced on March 23 2020.

description:
In France, from October 30, 2020 and for a duration of at least four weeks (with reassessment every two weeks) a national lockdown is declared. All travel by persons outside their place of residence is prohibited except for the following reasons : 
1. Travel to or from:
(a) The place where a person is engaged in or seeking employment, and business trips that cannot be postponed
b) establishments or services for the reception of minors, education or training for adults mentioned in articles 32 to 35 of this decree
c) The place where an examination or a competition is organized;
2. Travel to make purchases of supplies necessary for the professional activity, purchases of basic necessities, withdrawals of orders and home deliveries
3. Travel for consultations, examinations and treatments that cannot be provided at a distance and for the purchase of medication
4. Travel for compelling family reasons, for assistance to vulnerable and precarious people, for childcare, as well as for removals
5. Travel for disabled people and their companions
6. Short trips, within the limit of one hour per day and within a maximum radius of one kilometer around the home, related either to the individual physical activity of the persons, excluding any collective sports practice and any proximity with other persons, or to the walk with the only persons grouped in the same home, or to the needs of pets
7. Travel to respond to a judicial or administrative summons or to go to a public
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

1. Travel to or from:
(a) The place where a person is engaged in or seeking employment, and business trips that cannot be postponed

c) The place where an examination or a competition is organized;

description:
On March 31 2021, the French President Emmanuel Macron announced a nationwide lockdown in all French departments from April 3 2021 for four weeks. 

The full list of accepted reasons for going out are (no attestation form needed) were:
-Physical exercise, walking, walking the dog (within 10 km of your home)
-Shopping for basic necessities, or to pick up ordered goods
-Accompanying children to school or out-of-school activities
-Visiting a cultural establishment (libraries and media libraries) or a place of worship
-Attending to administrative or legal formalities

Permitted reasons for travelling outside your department with an attestation are: 
-For work, education and training, general interest missions
-Health reasons (consultations and care/treatment)
-Compelling family reasons, to help vulnerable or needy persons, or for childcare
-Transporting people with disabilities and their carers
-Judicial or administrative summons
-Moving home
-Transit travel to stations and airports 

Those living close to the border of their department are allowed to travel up to 30km from their home for the above reasons. Everyone who can should work from home, although there is still an exemption for one day a week of work in the workplace for people who feel their mental health is being affected by 100 percent home-working. Violations were punishable by fine and imprisonment.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: On July 30 2021, There is no recommendation to stay at home within metropolitan France. In Guadaloupe,  a curfew is in place between 21:00 and 5:00 from 30 July. In Martinique, a lockdown is in place from 19:00 to 5:00. From 5:00 to 19:00, only travel within a radius of 10km is allowed from a person's home, with exceptions for travel to work. Teleworking is recommended, whenever possible. Discotheques are closed. Restuarants are only allowed to serve customers at outdoor tables, or provide take-away services. Restuarants and bars located in enclosed shopping cetners over 5000m2 are not allowed to open, unless only accessible from a public road.      In La Reunion from July 31, a lockdown will be enforced from from 18:00 to 5:00. From 5:00 to 18:00, only travel within a radius of 10km on weekdays and 5km on weekends from a person's home will be allowed, beyond which proof of compelling reason for travel will be required.

description: France. In late February 2020, the City of Lyon formed a strategic and operational supervisory committee for managing the Covid-19 crisis. This committee is operational 7 days a week under the authority of the Mayor of Lyon. On March 17th, the city announced that the committee's functions range from planning for the elections that will take place in March and June, to organizing services for individuals in need due to the pandemic. On May 11th, 2020, the City of Lyon announced that the strategic and operational supervisory committee will begin working on Lyon's reopening plan.

description: On March 22, 2020 in Switzerland the three cantons of Basel-City, Basel-Landschaft and Jura announced that the French Departement Haut-Rhin sent an urgent request for support to the three cantons on March 20. In consultation with the federal authorities, the three governments have agreed that ICU patients from France can be transferred to the cantonal hospitals. Further Swiss cantons ( Aargau, Bern, Fribourg, Geneva, Lucerne, Neuchâtel, Saint Gallen, Schaffhausen, Thurgau, Vaud, Valais, Zurich ) offered help and took ICU patients from French regions Grand-Est and Franche-Comté.

description: On February 20, 2020, the French Health Ministry published a brochure for hospitals and health professionals on the current COVID situation. The document included information about the activation of MARS (Rapid Health Alerts), which can send out health alerts to different sectors of the health industry seven days a week. The alerts will be distributed rapidly and pertain to current guidelines. The document also calls for hospitals and other health agencies to host training for staff who will be in contact with COVID patients. Emergency care teaching centers, including SAMU (Urgent Medical Aid Service) and SMIT (Office of Infectious and Tropical Diseases) will help with this training. Staff will be taught how to effectively use personal protective equipment, how COVID is transmitted, how government health agencies will function, how cases are classified, and confidentiality for individuals exposed to COVID. The French Ministry of Health is currently the only group that can announce the number of confirmed cases and deaths.

description: On June 2, 2020, the French national government launched StopCovid. StopCovid is an app launched to alert people who are in contact with someone who tests positive for COVID-19. Both parties must have the app downloaded, and the individual with COVID must upload their test results for the app to work. UPDATE: On October 22, 2020, the French national government updated StopCovid. It is now called "TousAntiCovid" and added new functions to the app. Several online tools are set up within the scope of  the "Test-Alert-Protect" (Tester-Alerter-Protéger) strategy :  DépistageCovid (test) : a map that highlights the places where the citizens can do tests   MesConseilsCovid (Protect) : a website that provides advice on how to handle Covid-19 and live with it.

The films focus on informing blind/visually impaired people and those around them about practices to protect themselves from COVID: Washing your hands, going out, putting on a mask or knowing if you are a vulnerable person in the face of COVID-19. These videos provide useful details on barrier gestures that require more vigilance.

description: On September 25, 2020, the French national government shared printable posters with guidelines about wearing masks in order to protect oneself from new COVID-19 variants. Anyone can download the posters. These posters contained the following information: the government recommends wearing masks when maintaining a distance of 6 feet is not possible. Homemade masks should no longer be worn because they do not provide enough filtration. Healthcare professionals should wear FFP2 masks (without valves) or surgical masks, and citizens should wear cloth masks. People with COVID and hospital visitors should wear surgical masks. Masks must cover the chin, nose, and mouth and be fitted tightly to the face to be effective. People should wash their hands before putting on their masks and should not touch the mask once securing it to their faces.

description: From October 7 2020, the Regional Health Agency (ARS) of the Grand Est region of France launched a campaign aimed at students, encouraging them to the correct preventative behaviours ("barrier gestures") of Covid-19 (such as hand-washing, hygeine etc), even when they were asymptomatic. The campaign focused on encouraging a "controlled" social life. Four key settings for behaviour change were targeted the campaign - weekends with families, nights out with friends, sharing a car, and sharing study spaces at universities. Posters were available to download and print, information was provided on the ARS website, and were into shareable photos/GIFs for Facebook, Instagram and Snapchat.

description: On October 29, 2020, the Directorate of Legal and Administrative Information published a webpage explaining the current state of emergency in France. The webpage explains that a state of medical emergency can be declared by the law and provides the dates that the state of emergency was in effect. It also explains that the state of emergency temporarily limits the freedoms to travel and meet and allows the govenment to temporarily control prices. It highlights punishments of violating government guidelines (up to 6 months imprisonment and a 10,000 euro fine). The webpage includes a link to a Youtube video that explains why the state of emergency was declared and what it entails.

description: On November 3 2020, the French national government announced the launch of a special number of information on emergency measures for companies struggling due to the COVID-19 Pandemic: 0806 000 245 (non-premium rate call, price of a local call) effective from November 2nd, 2020 at 9 am. Help is available from 9 am to 12 pm and 1 pm to 4 pm Monday to Friday. Companies can call for information about their eligibility for aid or with other questions about the measures being taken to help businesses. The number is meant to be used in conjunction with the existing government website to aid businesses with responding to COVID (https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises).

description: On November 12, 2020, the French national goverment shared posters and social media graphics that anyone can download. The posters provide numbers that victims of domestic violence can call (17) or text (114) if they are in immediate danger. The posters also provide a number that allows women to speak with a professional (3919), a link to the French anti-domestic violence government website, and the name of an app (App-Elles). The posters reassure women that they can leave a dangerous situation despite lockdown restrictions.

description: On February 8, 2021, the French national government shared printable posters that explain how RNA messenger vaccines work. The posters explain the scientific principles of the vaccine in more accessible language. In a series of drawings and short descriptions, the graphic explains that the section of mRNA coding for the S protein of SARS-CoV-2 can be injected into humans in the form of a vaccine to teach their immune systems to fight it off. Anyone can download the posters.

description: On September 21, 2021, the French Ministry of Health published a website, responding to frequently asked questions about receiving booster doses of the COVID-19 vaccines. The site addresses who is eligible, why people should receive a booster, where boosters are being offered, and how many people have received boosters. The site also explains how vaccine passports will be updated to reflect the booster dose and reports how many people have currently received their booster shots. Currently, only people in higher risk categories (ex. those over 65, people with comorbidities, those who are immunocompromised). People who received the Janssen vaccine at least four weeks previously are eligible to receive a booster. The website contains a graphic that anyone can download. It shows eligibility by age and conditions and includes the link to the Health Ministry's website, where people can find more information.

description: On November 30, 2021, the French Ministry of Health shared a video to their Youtube channel encouraging people to get a booster dose of the COVID vaccine. The video features an elderly man and woman going to the pharmacy to ask for a booster shot. The video ends with the line, "There are some meetings/appointments you don't want to miss," and encourages everyone over the age of 18 who received their second shot or had COVID at least 5 months prior to sign up for the booster. The video tells people to contact their doctors to ask about receiving the booster or to visit the Ministry of Health website to make an appointment. The French government's Twitter page also shared the video.

description: From 25 May 2020 until June 15, 2020, the French Government is putting in place a voluntary 14-day quarantine measure for travelers arriving from countries outside the European area (includes all countries of the world except EU members, Andorra, Iceland, Lichtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland, Vatican City). There is an exception to this measure: for travelers arriving from European countries whose authorities have decided, in an uncoordinated fashion, to apply 14-day quarantine measures to travelers entering their territory from European countries, a voluntary 14-day quarantine period will be reciprocally requested. Therefore, travelers from UK and Spain are subject to a voluntary quarantine regardless of their nationality due to their country's policies.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
From Monday, January 18 2021, all travelers who wish to come to France, from a country outside the European Union will have to carry out a test before leaving. In addition, the persons concerned will have to undertake on their honor to isolate themselves for 7 days once they arrive in France, then redo a second PCR test at the end.
For the few countries where it is not possible to carry out a test on-site, the person will be tested on arrival in France and will be forced to isolate themselves for 7 days in an establishment designated by the State.

description: As of 24 January, France already requires travelers from outside the EU to produce proof of a negative PCR COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours prior to departure. However, travelers from outside the EU must also self-isolate for seven days on arrival, with a second test being required at the end of the isolation period. Travelers unable to take a test in the country of departure may do so on arrival but must submit to seven days of isolation at a government-designated facility.

description: Employees who work in the goods transport sector, logistic chain, or delivery men (people who can't work remotely) will remain active to ensure business continuity. Industrial warehouses will continue to operate abiding by health regulations. People who cannot work from home such as delivery men will remain worikng as normal but must present upon random inspection proof of business travel (for employees of companies or the public sector) OR an exceptional travel certificate for other non-salaried categories (example: self-employed workers, liberal professions other than health, etc.) Employees of Pays de la Loire must stay home if they are: sick or particularly vulnerable, are one of two parents who care for a child whose school is closed, who have the possibility of working remotely, or who are partially unemployed.

description:
Starting March 19, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health announced the following restrictions for goods transport companies in light of the COVID-19 pandemic
- the hygiene and social distancing measures, known as “barriers”, defined at national level, must be observed by the drivers of transport vehicles as well as by the personnel of the loading places or unloading
- vehicle must be equipped with water, soap, and disposable towels or hydro-alcoholic gel.
- delivery and signature of transport documents are carried out without contact between people.
- In the case of home deliveries, the drivers, after communication with the recipient or his representative, leave the packages at the door by implementing alternative methods which confirm the correct delivery and do not recover the recipient's signature

description:
Starting March 19, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced the following rules for drivers of taxis and transport cars in light of the COVID-19 pandemic
- drivers can deny access to the vehicle to anyone showing symptoms of covid-19 infection.
- passengers may not sit next to the driver
- the vehicle is permanently ventilated
- passengers must take all their waste with them.
- the driver performs disinfectant cleaning of the vehicle at least once a day.

description: Restaurants are required to follow strict rules as: 10 people maximum per table, a metre between tables and groups and patrons are not allowed to drink or eat standing up at bar. Only in orange zones (Ile- de-Frace and over seas territories of Mayotte and French Guiana) only restaurant and bar terraces are allowed to reopen; in Paris restaurants will be permitted to "spead out" into public spaces". Hotels and campsites, so as cultural and sport centres, are open in green zones, in orange zones must wait until june 22. Parks and gardens will reopen in alll zones. Wearing a mask will be mandatory in museums and touristic areas, and physical distancing measure must be respected. Weddings and public gatherings are allowed but phyical distancing measure must remain; public gathering of +10 people aren't allowed until june 21 and +5000 people remain banned until at least August 31.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
2 June 2020, France. Establishments can now open. Following recommendations from medical authority le Haut Conseil de la Santé Publique, the government has not imposed a mandatory four-metre-square limit around each table (as it had previously suggested it might), but restaurants are still required to respect strict rules, including:

10 people maximum per table
At least a metre between tables and groups
Patrons are not allowed to drink or eat standing up at the bar

description:
"From June 22, 2020 in France, and until further notice, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced that restaurants, bars, cafés, and hotel restaurants can reopen across all of France under the following conditions: 
(1) groups of no more than 10 per table
(2) minimum of one metre (3.3 feet) between tables, or with a screen in between.
(3) masks mandatory at all times for wait and kitchen staff
(4) masks mandatory for customers when not seated
(5) drinking at the counter in bars is prohibited
(6) seated places only (including in bars)

description: On October 5 2020, the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France announced the reopening of restaurants in Aix-en-Provence and Marseille. There are restrictions to respect :  - a ban on consumption while standing indoors or outdoors  - a distance of at least one meter between each chair -limit of the number of guests at the same table to six - obligation to wear a mask  -the maximum reception capacity respecting the measures mentioned  - set up a “reminder book” in order to keep the contact details of customers available to health authorities (14 days max).
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: From August 13, 2021, “the “sanitary pass” is required to attend the following:  “marquees, theaters, sporting or cultural performance venues, conference rooms;  trade shows and exhibition fairs (by exhibition hall);  outdoor establishments including zoological, amusement and theme parks;  stadiums, sports establishments, swimming pools, sports halls;  large casinos, arcades and bowling alleys;  outdoor sit / stand festivals;  cinemas and theaters;  monuments, museums and exhibition halls;  libraries, media libraries (excluding university and specialized libraries, BPI, BnF);  sports competition ;  other events, cultural, sporting, fun or festive, organized in public space or in a place open to the public and likely to give rise to control of the access of people.  worship establishments for events not of a religious nature;  ships and boats, cruise ship type  in discotheques, dance clubs and bars.  in fairgrounds, from a threshold of 30 stands or attractions.”  “commercial catering activities (bars and restaurants, including the terraces), with the exception of catering or takeaway ready meals, road professional catering (based on a list approved by decree prefectural) and rail, room service in hotel restaurants and bars and non-commercial catering, in particular the free distribution of meals;”

description:
In the public service in France, article 44 of law n°84-53 of January 26, 1984 prescribes that the aptitude lists are valid for a period of four years following the public service exam date.
Thus, on March 28, 2020 (announced on March 27, 2020), the President of France suspended the countdown of the validity period of these lists from March 12, 2020 until the end of the public health emergency, increased by two months to take into account the public health crisis.

description: On March 15, 2020, the Ministry of Justice of France announced that from March 16, 2020, public reception services and houses of justice can no longer receive the public. The agents of these services answer by telephone to emergency situations. Furthermore, all non-urgent hearings are postponed. The exceptions are: emergency criminal hearings; presentations before the investigating judge and the liberty and detention judge; emergency hearings for child custody; the prosecution service and emergency procedures before the civil judge, in particular for the eviction of a violent spouse.

description: On April 15, 2020, the President of France signed the Ordinance No. 2020-430 which requires civil servants and contractual agents of public law in the public service to take ten days off during the period of the health emergency. description:
From May 11, the prefecture of Corse-du-Sud has reopened with new methods of welcoming the public. 
(1) Prefecture access will be limited to those with appointments; waiting for an appointment inside the prefecture is prohibited. 
(2) The digital point located in reception will be accessible without an appointment from Monday to Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. and from 1:30 p.m. to 3:30 p.m for people who have difficulty carrying out digital procedures relating to vehicle registration certificates or driving licenses. Only one person can access the digital point at a time.

description: Sécurité Routière (Road Safety) announced a gradual resumption of activities in the traffic education sector from 11 May, 2020. From 11 May, 2020, theoretical and practical training resumed and some driving schools reopened; from 25 May, 2020, heavyweight (C and D) and motorcycle (A and A1) tests resumed; and from 8 June, 2020, category B driving license exams resumed. On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663 which allowed closed establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code, from June 2nd, 2020 to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely. UPDATE: The original policy announced that activities of motor driving license inspectors, and therefore practical and theoretical driving license exams, are interrupted for an indefinite period. Sécurité Routière (Road Safety) announced a gradual resumption of activities in the traffic education sector from 11 May, 2020. From 11 May, 2020, theoretical and practical training resumed and some driving schools reopened; from 25 May, 2020, heavyweight (C and D) and motorcycle (A and A1) tests resumed; and from 8 June, 2020, category B driving license exams resumed. On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663 which allowed closed establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code, from June 2nd, 2020 to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely.

Additionally, all study rooms will remain closed.

description: On the 19 March 2020, the Department of Meurthe-et-Moselle in the Grand Est region of France banned the collecting or cutting of wood in forests throughout the region. Sports and recreational activities, foraging/fruit picking, photography, and recreational fishing in forests, mountains and other open-air settings were also banned. UPDATE: On May 31 2020, the French national government ordered all lakes and beaches to reopen regardless of department colour on June 2 2021, effectively ending Meurthe-et-Moselle's ban on recreational fishing and other forest-related activities.

description: On June 17, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-742, which facilitates vote by proxy for the second round of the general renewal of municipal and community councilors, Paris councilors and Lyon metropolitan councilors set on June 28, 2020. Therefore, people who, due to the Covid-19 pandemic, cannot appear before the judicial police officers and agents empowered to establish powers of attorney or their delegates have the right to have the competent authorities come to establish or withdraw their power of attorney. The people mentioned in the previous paragraph may refer the matter to the competent authorities by post, by telephone or, where appropriate, by electronic means. These people indicate the reason for their inability to travel, without having to provide proof. The judicial police officers and agents empowered to establish the powers of attorney, or the delegates of these judicial police officers as well as the people whose power of attorney is obtained wear a mask

description: On November 18, 2020, the President of France signed Ordinance No. 2020-1401, which extends the authorization to contravene article 706-71 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and to use an audiovisual telecommunication means before all criminal courts without it being necessary to obtain the agreement of the parties.This is to last from November 19, 2020 until one month following the end of the state of health emergency declared by the decree of October 14, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy authorized, from March 26, 2020, to contravene article 706-71 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and to use an audiovisual telecommunication means before all criminal courts without it being necessary to obtain the agreement of the parties. On November 18, 2020, this authorization was extended until one month following the end of the state of health emergency declared by the decree of October 14, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On November 18, 2020, the President of France signed Ordinance No. 2020-1402, which extends the authorization of hearings of administrative jurisdictions to be held using audiovisual telecommunication means that guarantee the identity of the parties and guarantee the quality of transmission and the confidentiality of exchanges between the parties and their lawyers. This is to last from November 19, 2020 until one month following the end of the state of health emergency declared by the decree of October 14, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy authorized hearings of administrative jurisdictions to be held using audiovisual telecommunication means that guarantee the identity of the parties and guarantee the quality of transmission and the confidentiality of exchanges between the parties and their lawyers from March 26, 2020. On November 18, 2020, this authorization was extended but no end date was given.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On November 27, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1454, which allows librairies, documentation and centers to welcome the public as of November 28, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy prohibited librairies and documentation centers to welcome the public in France. As of November 28, 2020, librairies and documentation centers will be allowed to welcome the public.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government

description: On November 27, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1454, which extends the closure of establishments of category L (hearing, conference, meeting, performance and multipurpose rooms). However, courtrooms, crematoriums and rooms for activities of professional artists are allowed to remain open. However, the managers of these establishments must ensure that the people welcomed have a seat and that a minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than six people coming together or having booked together. Mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old. This is to last from November 28, 2020, but no end date has been given. UPDATE: The original policy set the closure of establishments of category L (hearing, conference, meeting, performance and multipurpose rooms) to December1, 2020. On November 27, 2020 it was extended but no end date was given.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On November 27, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No.2020-1454, which extends the closure of large museums and rooms intended for temporarily cultural exhibitions. UPDATE: The original policy prohibited the opening of large museums and rooms intended for temporarily cultural exhibitions to open to the public from October 30, 2020 until at least December 1, 2020. On November 27, 2020, the closure was extended, but no end date was given.

description:
On December 24, 2020, the President of France signed Ordinance No. 2020-1694, which extends the suspension of the four-year validity period of the aptitude lists in the public service required under article 44 of the Law of January 26, 1984, from January 1, 2021 to April 30, 2021.
 UPDATE: The original policy fixed the suspension of the four-year validity period of the aptitude lists in the public service required under article 44 of the Law of January 26, 1984 from March 12, 2020 until the end of the public health emergency, increased by two months. On December 24, 2020, the President of France extended the suspension from January 1, 2021 to April 30, 2021.

description: On February 3rd, 2021, the President of France signed Ordinance No. 2021-112, which authorizes career military personnel who have reached the age limit and contract military personnel who have reached the term of service limit to be retained in service for a maximum of one year due to the pandemic.This ordinance also authorizes former professional soldiers who had been struck off the roll for less than three years to return to service until they reach the age limit.These measures are expected to remain in effect for a period of six months after the end of the current state of health emergency.

description: On February 28, 2020, the French government announced that: in general, indoor gatherings of more than 5,000 people are prohibited in France. In the most affected area north of Paris, all public gatherings are banned, hence the 4T instead of 1G coding. "The government has also banned all public gatherings in Oise, north of Paris, and in La Balme-de-Sillingy, a town in the French Alps where cases have been reported."   "In the department of Oise, the main outbreak, and in the town of La Balme-de-Sillingy, in the Haute-Savoie region, all public gatherings - including masses - are banned 'until further notice'."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 4, 2020, the Minister of Health and Solidarity announced that any gathering of more than 5,000 people simultaneously in an enclosed environment is prohibited on national territory. The representative of the State in the department is empowered to prohibit or restrict, including by individual measures, other gatherings when local circumstances so require.

description: On March 4, in the French region Morbihan, the general ban on gathering was replaced by a ban on gatherings "involving prolonged promiscuity of people promoting the transmission of the virus" (such as schools, markets, swimming pools), in epidemic centers and outside. UPDATE: The original policy was a general ban, it has been corrected to be a ban on gatherings "involving prolonged promiscuity of people promoting the transmission of the virus" (such as schools, markets, swimming pools ), in epidemic centers and outside.

description: From March 9 until March 22, the the prefects of Corsica and Corse-du-Sud in France announced a ban on gatherings of more than 50 people in the municipality of Ajaccio. Ceremonies in places of worship (weddings, funerals, baptisms) are maintained by limiting the number of participants. This prohibition does not apply to the normal activity of shops, businesses, restaurants, and bars, but seminars, parties et cetera of more than 50 people are prohibited.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
From March 9, 2020 unti April 15, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has banned any gathering bringing together more than 1,000 people simultaneously in a closed or open environment on national territory.

Gatherings essential to the continuity of the life of the Nation may be maintained by way of derogation by the State representative in the department, by regulatory or individual measures, except when local circumstances preclude it. The State representative is empowered for the same purposes, by regulatory or individual measures, to prohibit or restrict meetings, gatherings or activities not falling under the first paragraph when local circumstances so require.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From March 9, 2020 unti April 15, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has banned any gathering bringing together more than 1,000 people simultaneously in a closed or open environment on national territory.

Gatherings essential to the continuity of the life of the Nation may be maintained by way of derogation by the State representative in the department, by regulatory or individual measures, except when local circumstances preclude it. The State representative is empowered for the same purposes, by regulatory or individual measures, to prohibit or restrict meetings, gatherings or activities not falling under the first paragraph when local circumstances so require. UPDATE: On April 14, 2020, the ban on gatherings of 100 people was extended until May 11, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In France, from May 23, 2020, the National Government has announced that gatherings and meetings in places of worship are allowed to resume, but only under certain conditions. Attendance must be limited to a maximum threshold such that all who attend can maintain a distance of at least one meter between two people. Masks are mandatory for all those in attendance aged 11 or older, and hand disinfection will be mandatory at the entrance to places of worship. The departmental prefect can prohibit these gatherings if these conditions are not met.

description: This year's delayed three-week Tour de France race starts on Saturday, 29 August and runs until 20 September. All team members have to undergo two diagnostic tests for Covid-19, six days and three days ahead of the start, while they have to compile a health check questionnaire twice a day during the race. Riders and team staff will be in a bubble from the day they arrive in Nice before the Grand Depart. They will be tested twice before the race starts, and a mobile testing lab will also be available. If a team has two positive cases or [members] with strong symptoms within a seven-day period, they will be out of the race.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On September 14, 2020, Marseille and Aix-en-Provence limit public gatherings to 1000 and put additional restrictions on private gatherings. That limit covers places like stadiums and concert halls, as well as demonstrations. Cafes and restaurants will also no longer be able to serve clients who are standing up and will not be able to play music outdoors. Dancing is forbidden in public venues, including at weddings.  In these regions including Bordeaux, the government officials announced a ban on gatherings of more than 10 people in public parks, along the citys picturesque river and on beaches. Fun fairs, antique fairs and neighborhood parties are also banned.The regional government also asked Bordeaux residents to limit private family gatherings, singling out weddings, to a maximum of 10 people.

description:
On October 29th 2020, the French government announced that:
I. - The establishments of worship, falling under category V (Establishments in which the number of members of the public does not reach the minimum figure set by the safety regulations for each type of operation), are authorized to remain open. Any gathering or meeting within them is prohibited except for funeral ceremonies up to a limit of 30 people.
II. - Anyone eleven years of age or over who accesses or remains in these establishments wears a protective mask.
The obligation to wear a mask does not prevent it from being temporarily removed for the performance of the rites that require it.
III. - The manager of the place of worship ensures at all times, and in particular when entering and leaving the building, that the provisions mentioned in this article are respected.
IV. - The departmental prefect may, after formal notice remains unanswered, prohibit the reception of the public in religious establishments if the conditions of their organization as well as the controls put in place are not such as to guarantee compliance with the provisions. mentioned in this article.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On January 22 2020, in France, the Mission COREB (Coordination Opérationnelle Risque Epidémique et Biologique) nationale informed the protocol that 1st line should follow when treating patients suspected of having COVID-19.These are, if patient had symptoms (fever and couph): give them a face mask; search for any symptoms of severity, possible comorbidities. Sympthomatic treatment, if vital emergency. Make a clinical-epidemiological analysis to estimate the diagnostic probability. In case of being a possible result , call the infectiologist of the health facilities and alert the ARS (Agence Régionale de Santé). If patient remains suspect,treat for few hours at ES of first contact, precautions above maintained until classification; adapted treatment of possible alternative. Also includes questions that 1st line medical staff should ask patients.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_province: China: Beijing,Guangdong,Henan,Shaanxi,Shanxi; Japan: Tokyo; South Korea: Seoul; Thailand: Bangkok
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On March 11 2020, the French Health Minister suspended all visitations to all aged-care homes (Établissement d'hébergement pour personnes âgées dépendantes, EHPAD) and long-term care units (unités de soins de longue durée, USLD) across the country. Visitation to auntonomous residents was also highly discouraged. Exceptions could be made by the director of the establishment, based on the advice of Regional Health Agencies or Prefectures. 
This policy is in effect until further notice.

description:
Starting March 19, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health announced the following restrictions for goods transport companies in light of the COVID-19 pandemic
- the hygiene and social distancing measures, known as “barriers”, defined at national level, must be observed by the drivers of transport vehicles as well as by the personnel of the loading places or unloading
- vehicle must be equipped with water, soap, and disposable towels or hydro-alcoholic gel.
- delivery and signature of transport documents are carried out without contact between people.
- In the case of home deliveries, the drivers, after communication with the recipient or his representative, leave the packages at the door by implementing alternative methods which confirm the correct delivery and do not recover the recipient's signature
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Transportation (land; water and air)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
From March 19, 2020 in France, the Ministry of Soldidarity and Health is mandating that all bus and train operators take the following social distancing measures: 
- take all appropriate measures to separate the driver from travelers by a distance of at least one meter and inform travelers (unless proven technically impossible)
- prohibit travelers from using the front door in vehciles with multiple doors, and allow them to enter and exit through any other door. 
- permit use of the front door when arrangements have been made to separate the driver from travelers by a distance of at least one meter
In the event of non-compliance with these social distancing measures, a ban may be placed on transport service on all the lines concerned.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keep a distance of some other distance not listed above. Please note the distance in meters in the text entry.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
On May 7 2020, the French government confirmed that public tranposrt users in the Île-de-France region will have to present a professional certificate or a compelling reason to travel during rush hour when public tranport re-opens on May 11. 
Permitted reasons include: 
1. Travel for work which cannot be postponed.
2. Travel to school or to an exam.
3. Travel for medical appointments that cannot be completed through video meetings.
4. Travel for urgent family reasons including caring for children or a vulnerable individual.
5. Travel to court or police station

description:
On April 30, 2020, French government announced the plan to encourage people to take their bikes instead of public transport after a nationwide coronavirus lockdown ends on May 11. People can benefit from a subsidy of up to 50 euros to fix them and from free training to learn to ride safely, with an experienced instructor. Objective is to reduce overcrowding in metros and buses, where it is hard to practice the social distancing required to prevent virus transmission. 
The €50 subsidy, initially available until the end of 2020, is available until March 31st 2021, Environment Minister Barbara Pompili said on November 30th 2020.

description: Restaurants are required to follow strict rules as: 10 people maximum per table, a metre between tables and groups and patrons are not allowed to drink or eat standing up at bar. Only in orange zones (Ile- de-Frace and over seas territories of Mayotte and French Guiana) only restaurant and bar terraces are allowed to reopen; in Paris restaurants will be permitted to "spead out" into public spaces". Hotels and campsites, so as cultural and sport centres, are open in green zones, in orange zones must wait until june 22. Parks and gardens will reopen in alll zones. Wearing a mask will be mandatory in museums and touristic areas, and physical distancing measure must be respected. Weddings and public gatherings are allowed but phyical distancing measure must remain; public gathering of +10 people aren't allowed until june 21 and +5000 people remain banned until at least August 31.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Restaurants
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On May 31, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-663, which allowed establishments of category L (hearing, conference, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms) to open in green departments from June 2, 2020 under three conditions (first, mask wearing is mandatory in these establishments for people over 11 years old. Furthermore, the managers of these establishments must ensure that the people welcomed have a seat and that a minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than ten people coming together or having booked together). The same decree prohibited hearing, conference, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms to open except for courtrooms in orange departments from June 2, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other public facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
June 1, 2020. All collèges and schools on mainland France will now reopen, as will lycées in green zones.

These will reopen gradually, so not all students will restart classes today.

Masks are mandatory for all students when moving around, and for all staff taking care of children. Teachers, however, do not need to wear a mask “when they are giving a class and are at least one metre away from students”.

All of these rules are set to be re-evaluated from June 22.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
2 June 2020, France. Establishments can now open. Following recommendations from medical authority le Haut Conseil de la Santé Publique, the government has not imposed a mandatory four-metre-square limit around each table (as it had previously suggested it might), but restaurants are still required to respect strict rules, including:

10 people maximum per table
At least a metre between tables and groups
Patrons are not allowed to drink or eat standing up at the bar
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In France from May 18, 2020, middle schools can reopen in green departments only, starting with sixième (age 11) and cinquième (age 12). Classes sizes are limited to only 15 students per class and masks are mandatory for all faculty and students. UPDATE: The original reopening of middle schools applied to only green departments. However, starting June 2, middle schools will reopen in all departments in France, regardless of color designation.

description:
On May 7 2020, the French government confirmed that public tranposrt users in the Île-de-France region will have to present a professional certificate or a compelling reason to travel during rush hour when public tranport re-opens on May 11. 
Permitted reasons include: 
1. Travel for work which cannot be postponed.
2. Travel to school or to an exam.
3. Travel for medical appointments that cannot be completed through video meetings.
4. Travel for urgent family reasons including caring for children or a vulnerable individual.
5. Travel to court or police station UPDATE: Another travel type permitted was added as a compelling reason to travel related to the professional transport certificate.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions ridership of other forms of public transportation (please include details in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: From June 17, 2020, in France, elderly homes that do no report any possible or confirmed COVID-19 cases, must establish plans for a gradual return to "normality" before june 22, 2020. Medical staff in coordination with Établissement d'hébergement pour personnes âgées dépendantes (EHPAD) medics are working together to create these plans. They're going to be presented to the Conseil de la vie sociale CVS on behalf of residents and family. The plans must guarantee the resupmtion of family visits without a date, so as other activities (social life, end of closure on rooms, paramedical intervention and admissions to permanent accommodation and nurseries)

description:
"From June 22, 2020 in France, and until further notice, the Ministry of Solidarity and Health has annouced that restaurants, bars, cafés, and hotel restaurants can reopen across all of France under the following conditions: 
(1) groups of no more than 10 per table
(2) minimum of one metre (3.3 feet) between tables, or with a screen in between.
(3) masks mandatory at all times for wait and kitchen staff
(4) masks mandatory for customers when not seated
(5) drinking at the counter in bars is prohibited
(6) seated places only (including in bars)

description: On July 10, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-860, which extended the opening of establishments of category L (hearing, conference, projection, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms) in the territories that have emerged from the public health emergency. However, the managers of these establishments must ensure that the people welcomed have a seat and that a minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than ten people coming together or having booked together. Mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old. The same decree prohibited hearing, conference, projection, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms to reopen in the territories where the state of emergency is still in force (Guyane and Mayotte).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other public facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On July 10, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-860, which allows campsites and trailer parks to welcome the public in territories that have emerged from the health emergency as of July 11, 2020. A physical distance of at least one meter between two people must be observed at all times, but if it is not possible mask wearing is mandatory. This decree also forbids campsites and trailer parks to welcome the public in territories where the health emergency is still in force (Guyane and Mayotte) except for those that are considered permanent homes for the people who live there (Category PA).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On July 10, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-860, which allows establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely. A physical distance of at least one meter between two people has to be observed and mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old. This is to last from July 11, 2020, but no end date has been given. UPDATE: The original policy allowed closed establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely from June 2, 2020. On July 10, 2020 it was extended, but no end date was given.

description:
France. August 3rd, 2020.
Wearing a mask in certain outdoor public spaces has been made mandatory in some French towns and cities. In Nice, the mayor has declared that everyone is required to wear a mask in many areas of the southern French city, including parts of the famous Promenade des Anglais. Masks now have to be worn in 69 towns in Mayenne, in the north-west of France, where data has shown the virus is actively circulating. Biarritz, Bayonne, Saint-Malo, Le Touquet and Orleans have also imposed face coverings in the centre of town and in outdoor markets.

description: On June 19, 2020, the mayor of Sarcelles, a city in the Val d'Oise department in the Ile-de-France region, issued a municipal decree making it compulsory to wear a face mask inside stores within the city. UPDATE: On August 29 2020, the Prefecture of the Department of Val-d'Oise in the Ile-de-France region in France extended the wearing of masks in the city of Sarcelles. In addition to shops, transport, markets and closed places, wearing a mask will be compulsory in several outdoor spaces that will be indicated in the form of posters from August 31 onwards. People who do not wear a mask in these new areas will be subject to a fixed fine of € 135.

Visits are allowed, but all visitors have to take a COVID-19  test or an antigen test 72 hours before the visit, and to fill in a COVID-19-related questionnaire to establish the risk of entering the facility. description: On October 5 2020, the Department of Bouches-du-Rhône in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region of France announced the reopening of restaurants in Aix-en-Provence and Marseille. There are restrictions to respect :  - a ban on consumption while standing indoors or outdoors  - a distance of at least one meter between each chair -limit of the number of guests at the same table to six - obligation to wear a mask  -the maximum reception capacity respecting the measures mentioned  - set up a “reminder book” in order to keep the contact details of customers available to health authorities (14 days max).
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
On October 16th, 2020, French government imposed several measures that must be observed throughout France: 
-Social distancing of 1 metter; social gatherings must follow these measures, if activity doesn't force to wear mask, admin. can decide to force it or not; if not wearing a mask, distancing must be of 2 metters  
-People aged 11 or over must present a negative screening examination carried out less than 72 hours before crossing or travel by public air transport, so as a sworn statements attesting doesn't have symptoms, haven´t been in contact with a confirmed case in the 14 days preceding the flight, accepting an examination can be carried out on his arrival, and undertakes to respect a prophylatic isolation of 7 days.  
-Any person aged eleven or over who accessses or remains in vehicles or in spaced accesibel to public and assigned to public transport wears a protective mask.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On October 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1262, which allows establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely. A physical distance of at least one meter between two people has to be observed and mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old. This is to last from October 16, 2020, but no end date has been given. UPDATE: The original policy allowed closed establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely from June 2, 2020. On July 10, 2020 it was extended, but no end date was given. On October 16, 2020, it was extended again, but no end date was given.

description: On October 29, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1310, which forbids establishments of category L (hearing, conference, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms) to open to the public. However, courtrooms, crematoriums and rooms for activities of professional artists are allowed to remain open, but mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old. This is to last from October 30, 2020 until at least December 1, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy allowed establishments of category L (hearing, conference, projection, meeting, performance or multipurpose rooms) to open in all departments of France. description: On October 29, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1310, which allows establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code (driving schools) to dispense practical driving classes. A physical distance of at least one meter between two people has to be observed and mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old. This is to last from October 30, 2020 until at least December 1, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy allowed closed establishments mentioned in Book II of the Highway Code to welcome the public to dispense the training for the obtention of a driving license if these establishments can't insure this training remotely from June 2, 2020. On July 10, 2020 it was extended, but no end date was given. On October 16, 2020, it was extended again, but no end date was given. On October 19, 2020, it was extended again at least until December 1st, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On October 29, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1320, which forbids campsites and trailer parks to welcome the public except when they constitute a permanent home for the people who live there. This is to last from October 30, 2020 until at least December 1, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy allowed campsites and trailer parks to be open in all departments of France. From October 30, 2020 and at least December 1, 2020, campsites and trailer parks can no longer welcome the public except when they constitute a permanent home for the people who live there.

description: On October 29, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1310, which forbids large museums and rooms intended for temporarily cultural exhibitions to open to the public. This is to last from October 30, 2020 until at least December 1, 2020. UPDATE: The original policy established new conditions for the opening of large museums in France. On October 29, 2020, it was decided that all large museums and rooms intended for temporarily cultural exhibitions could no longer welcome the public. This is to last from October 30, 2020 until at least December 1, 2020.

description: According to the source of November 10, 2020, education minister of France provides more distant course options a week before that, as at least 50% of students attend in person most of the time. Masks are compulsory for all teachers as well as students aged six and over in all educational institutions throughout France.

description: On November 27, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1454, which allows librairies, documentation centers and archive preservation centers to welcome the public as of November 28, 2020, but no end date has been given. The managers of these establishments must ensure that a minimum distance of one seat is left between the seats occupied by each person or each group of less than six people coming together or having booked together. Mask wearing is mandatory for people older than 11 years old.

description: On November 27, 2020, the Prime Minister of France signed the decree No. 2020-1454, which extends the opening of beaches and lakes. description:
On December 12th, 2020, French government announced a policy for long term care facilities for the elderly (EHPAD - établissements d'hébergement pour personnes âgées dépendantes) that includes the following guidelines:  
o Strict hygiene measures (masks, handwashing, social distancing, disinfection,   
o Visits are allowed, but all visitors have to take a COVID-19  test or an antigen test 72 hours before the visit, and to fill in a COVID-19-related questionnaire to establish the risk of entering the facility.   
oVisits should only take place in outside spaces.  oLimit visits to families to exceptional circumstances              
Note: from 15 Dec, to alleviate feelings of loneliness during the Christmas and New Year’s season, elderly care residents will be able to receive visitors in their rooms and leave their residence in the period between 15th Dec and 3rd Jan. On returning to their facility, they will have to take a Covid-19 test (PCR or antigen). And cannot participate in group activities for 7 days after their return.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description:
France, December 15th, 2020
With regard to visits by relatives to establishments, the conditions remain regulated  visits by appointment . However, an increase in the gauges  number of visitors per resident and maximum number of visitors welcomed simultaneously by appointment slot  and in the duration of the appointment slots may be considered in order to facilitate the organization of visits and allow families to meet in more friendly conditions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
France, December 23rd, 2020
A growing number of French cities now require cloth face coverings in outdoor areas throughout or in designated parts of the city. This includes Paris and its suburbs, where cloth face coverings are required in all outdoor locations. Rules vary by city and can change quickly.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: According to the Minister of Education of France, from January 14, 2021, the government would roll out a mass-testing scheme in schools, testing up to one million pupils and teachers each month: "Every time there are three cases (discovered), a screening team will be sent to the premises". In the canteens, pupils in the same class will eat together every day and at the same table. High school pupils in terminale (third and final year) would have to be present “as much as possible”. The government announced that all indoor sports were temporarily suspended. This includes out-of-school activities. First-year university students will be authorised to return to their courses on-site, but with reduced numbers of participants, from January 25th.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On October 16th, 2020, French government announced several measures that must be observed: 
-Social distancing of 1 metter; social gatherings must follow these measures, if activity doesn't force to wear mask, admin. can decide to force it or not; if not wearing a mask, distancing must be of 2 metters  
-People aged 11 or over must present a negative screening examination carried out less than 72 hours before crossing or travel by public air transport, so as a sworn statements attesting doesn't have symptoms, haven´t been in contact with a confirmed case in the 14 days preceding the flight, accepting an examination can be carried out on his arrival, and undertakes to respect a prophylatic isolation of 7 days.  
-Any person aged eleven or over who accessses or remains in vehicles or in spaced accesibel to public and assigned to public transport wears a protective mask. UPDATE: From January 27th, 2020, in France, President Macron announced that physical distancing between 2 people must be of at least 2 metters.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

-Any person aged eleven or over who accessses or remains in vehicles or in spaced accesibel to public and assigned to public transport wears a protective mask. UPDATE: President Macron announced that social distancing between 2 people must be of at least 2 metters, not 1.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
On October 16th, 2020, French government announced several measures that must be observed: 
-Social distancing of 1 metter; social gatherings must follow these measures, if activity doesn't force to wear mask, admin. can decide to force it or not; if not wearing a mask, distancing must be of 2 metters  
-People aged 11 or over must present a negative screening examination carried out less than 72 hours before crossing or travel by public air transport, so as a sworn statements attesting doesn't have symptoms, haven´t been in contact with a confirmed case in the 14 days preceding the flight, accepting an examination can be carried out on his arrival, and undertakes to respect a prophylatic isolation of 7 days.  
-Any person aged eleven or over who accessses or remains in vehicles or in spaced accesibel to public and assigned to public transport wears a protective mask.
UPDATE: On February 12th, 2021, in France, President Macron announced that wearing a face mask is now mandatory for all children at educational facilities aged 6 years and older.
 UPDATE: On February 12th, 2021, in France, President Macron announced that wearing a face mask is now mandatory for all children at educational facilities aged 6 years and older.

description: Since July 21, 2021, French government imposed a new protocol in Établissement d'hébergement pour personnes âgées dépendantes  (EHPAD) and nursing homes provides that: measures implemented to protect residents are the same as in the general population; visits of relatives can be made without appointment in room as in the collective spaces; It is no longer required to complete a self-assessment upon arrival. The traceability register is maintained; Exits are allowed, without limitation of collective activities on return (except in case of contact at risk), but by maintaining screening for unvaccinated residents; Day receptions are normally open. Family visits can now be made without an appointment, in rooms as in collective spaces. They will be organized so that distancing is respected with other residents/families of residents. Vaccination is mandatory for all persons in contact with frail persons (caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description: On July 28, 2021, the Minister for National Education of France announced a new policy for middle and high schools to be implemented from the start of the new school year on September 2. A four-tier system of restrictions will be in place with controls depending on the incidence of COVID-19. Level 1 (Green): In-person learning at all levels. Level 2 (Yellow): In-person learning at all levels. Level 3 (Orange): In-person learning at primary and middle schools, hybrid learning (alternating distance and in-person learning) in high schools. Level 4 (Red): In-person learning in primary schools, hybrid learning for 50% of 3rd year, all 4th year and high school students. Increasing levels of sanitary requirements, mask-wearing, restrictions on sports, and protocols for contact tracing will be applied at each level.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: June 3, 2020: The Italian national news broadcaster RAI announced that the Health Ministers of Italy, Germany, France and The Netherlands have signed an alliance to research and produce a vaccine against COVID-19.

description: June 3, 2020: The Government of the Netherlands announced that “France, Germany, Italy and the Netherlands are joining forces in negotiations with potential developers and manufacturers of a coronavirus vaccine. Together, the 4 countries are exploring promising vaccine initiatives and are in discussions with a number of pharmaceutical companies. They intend to have the vaccines manufactured in Europe if possible.” Therefore, the 4 countries have “agreed to form the ‘Inclusive Vaccine Alliance’. According to the alliance, one of the most urgent matters at hand is to accelerate the development process and ensure global access to an effective vaccine.”

description: On January 31, 2020 the Federal Office of Foreign Affairs of Switzerland informed at its press conference, that the Swiss authorities are not planning their own repatriation operation for Swiss citizens from Hubai Province in China. The Flight back is organized together with France. The plan is for the flight from China to France to head for the port city of Marseille. On February 7 it was confirmet that the Swiss citizens and their family returned on the evacuation flight on February 3. The FDFA would help with the return to Switzerland after the end of the 14 day quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
